Morgan hit 17 sixes and set a new record in one-day international cricket, which saw his side win by 150 runsEconomists agree that the housing market will suffer if Britain leaves the EU without a deal.&nbspThe government’s spending watchdog, the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), forecast last month that house prices would tumble by almost 6 per cent in 2020 and another 3 per cent in 2021. The slide could be even steeper as the OBR’s prediction was based on the assumption of a particular type of no-deal Brexit – the less disruptive of the two laid out by the IMF earlier this year.Howard Archer, economic adviser to the EY Item&nbspClub, forecasts a similar decline, saying house prices would quickly fall by about 5 per cent as the economy weakened and the market was mired in acute uncertainty over Britain’s future trading relationship with the EU.For now, house prices look on track for hardly any growth over this year.&nbspAccording to RICS, a net balance of 9 per cent of respondents reported a fall in average prices over the past three months in England and Wales. Samuel Tombs, economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said the result is consistent with the official measure of prices showing a rise of only 0.5 per cent in 2019.&nbspHalifax data also showed that UK house prices dropped slightly in July for the second consecutive month and now stand at £236,120 on average.“The market continues to tread water,” said Russell Galley, managing director at Halifax.&nbsp“In the longer term, we believe there is unlikely to be a step change in market activity until buyers and sellers see some form of resolution to the current economic uncertainty.”RICS echoed this prediction, noting that its survey now points to zero growth in sales – as well as a steeper fall in prices – in the next three months.On Thursday Boris Johnson reiterated his trademark message that Britain will leave the EU on 31 October, even though no progress has been made on securing a withdrawal agreement acceptable to both sides.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsAs it happened EndedFollow the latest business newsClick to followThe IndependentFood firms are urging the government to waive parts of competition law to allow them to work together to minimise disruption to supplies in the event of a no-deal Brexit.Meanwhile, the pound remains close to the 30-month low of $1.21 reached last week but is up slightly against the dollar and euro, despite news on Brexit appearing to worsen this morning.Senior Tory&nbspMPs&nbsphave suggested that the Queen may have to step in&nbspto&nbspuse prerogative powers to remove&nbspBoris Johnson as prime minister if he refused to step down after a potential no-confidence vote.Mr Johnson, whose government has a majority of just one MP, could face a no-confidence vote if he attempts to push through no-deal as promised on 31 October.Please allow the liveblog below a moment to load:Good morning and welcome to The Independent's live coverage of business and economics events around the world.&nbsp&nbspFood suppliers have warned that the UK would need 30 large empty warehouses to store even a week's extra food supply and there is currently no spare capacity in the country to deal with a chaotic Brexit in less than three months.&nbsp“In the event of no-deal disruption, if the Government wants the food supply chain to work together to tackle likely shortages - to decide where to prioritise shipments - they will have to provide cast-iron written reassurances that competition law will not be strictly applied to those discussions,” FDF's chief operating officer Tim Rycroft told the BBC.&nbspIn the markets, Asian stocks were down on Wednesday while European bourses gained in morning trading.&nbspDominic Raab, the foreign secretary, has&nbsppraised Donald Trump and his deputy Mike Pence for their warmth and enthusiasm for the UK-US relationship.&nbspRaab says he was delighted to meet the pair on his three-day trip to the US in hope of paving the way for a post-Brexit trade deal.The UK looks forward to working with our American friends to reach a free trade deal that is good for both countries, and co-operating on the common security challenges we face.&nbspE.On is the latest “Big Six” energy supplier to blame the government’s price cap for plummeting profits.The cap, which will be reduced this winter, is supposed to stop firms ripping off loyal customers.The German utility’s earnings from UK retail customers crashed 78 per cent in the latest quarter.Customer numbers fell by around 200,000 to 6.4 million in the three months to March.Bad news for E.On today but good news for about 15 million households who will see their energy bills fall this winter.&nbspAnnual energy bills will go down by £75 on average for 11 million households on standard tariffs and by £25 for customers who pay for their gas and electricity upfront.&nbspOfgem, the energy regulator for England, Wales and Scotland, is lowering the price caps for the October to March period due to lower wholesale energy prices.Full story here from Olesya Dmitracova:Energy bills to fall for 15 million households this winter as Ofgem lowers price capsExecutives at Hargreaves Lansdown will give up their bonuses after the Woodford fund fiasco, Reuters&nbspis reporting.&nbspAccording to the nes agency's source, Hargreaves' chief executive Chris Hill, Chief financial officer Philip Johnson, chief investment officer Lee Gardhouse and research director Mark Dampier, will take no bonus for 2019.&nbspHargreaves plugged Woodford's fund through its best buy list and received fees for referring customers.&nbspHundreds of thousands of Hargreaves Lansdown customers who ploughed their savings into Woodford's flagship fund have had their money frozen since June and it will likely stay there until at least December as the once highly regarded stock picker tries to sort out the mess he is in.&nbspWoodford invested in riskier unlisted stocks which he couldn't get rid of fast enough when a long run of poor performance prompted people to demands their cash back.House prices have fallen for the second successive month, Halifax says.The average UK house price was down 2 per cent in July to&nbsp£236,120 following a 0.4 per cent monthly decline in June.However, the lender said prices were still up 4.1 per cent in the year to July.Brexit uncertainty will weigh on the UK housing market over the next few months according to analysts at the EY ITEM Club.&nbspConsumers may well be particularly cautious about committing to buying a house, especially as house prices are relatively expensive relative to incomes, says Howard Archer.&nbspHouse prices are still far higher compared to earnings than the average over the last 35 years.&nbspAccording to the Halifax, the house price to earnings ratio was still as high as 5.59 in July after spiking to 5.72 in February (the highest level since November 2017) from 5.39 in January this is well above the long-term (1983-2019) average of 4.29.&nbspAnd it is questionable whether recent growth in jobs numbers and earnings can be sustained months as companies tailor their behaviour to a lacklustre domestic economy, prolonged Brexit uncertainties and a challenging global environment.&nbspTherefore Archer forecats&nbspthat house prices will rise by no more than 1.5 per cent in 2019.&nbsp&nbspTesla is in a spot of bother in the US.&nbspBloomberg&nbspreports that Elon Musk's firm has been scrutinised over safety claims on its Model 3 the car intended to take electric vehicles truly into the mainstream.&nbsp&nbspUS&nbspNational Highway Traffic Administration reportedly sent a cease and desist letter last year, taking issue with Tesla's&nbspclaim that the Model 3 had achieved the lowest probability of injury of any vehicle the agency ever tested.So, what exactly is Britain's food industry saying it needs the government to do to prevent food shortages after Brexit?&nbspIt's trade body wants firms&nbspto be allowed&nbspco-ordinate and direct supplies with each other if Britain crashes out of the EU on 31 October.&nbspThey cant do that under current rules which prevent them colluding. Those&nbspmeasures are designed to ensure adequate competition and result in the best outcome for consumers.The Food and Drink Federation (FDF) said: “We asked for these reassurances at the end of last year, but we're still waiting.”&nbspThe industry says that an October Brexit would be disastrous for food supplies because warehouses are already full in the run-up to Christmas.&nbsp&nbspOne retailer told the BBC that 31 October&nbsp“is about the worst day you can pick”, as warehouse capacity is at 105 per cent&nbspin November, versus 75 per cent - 80 per cent&nbspin March.The government isn't being entirely up-front about the potentially dire consequences of no-deal Brexit for fresh food and drink supplies, according to a leading academic on the topic.&nbspTim Lang, professor of food policy at City University, warned earlier this week that the UK’s food supply faces levels of disruption “unprecedented” in peacetime.&nbspWhat does that mean?&nbsp&nbsp	The government estimates that half of lorries entering the country will be unable to cross the border smoothly	The flow of trucks could drop by a third within a day of a no-deal Brexit	Food prices predicted to rise by more than 10 per cent as costs rise and supplies fall.Professor Lang warns&nbspthat Britons, particularly those on lower incomes, already under-consume fresh fruit and vegetables, and food banks are not fully prepared for shortages, which could have a negative impact on diets and public health.&nbspFull story here:&nbsp&nbspBrexit food shortages: Government being secretive over public health risks of no dealThousands of holidaymakers have had their flights cancelled due to more technology failures at British Airways.&nbspSimon Calder has counted&nbsp86 cancellations to and from Heathrow so far today, including one round-trip to New York and dozens of flights to Mediterranean resorts. A further 10 have been cancelled at Gatwick.&nbspThe full report, including details on which flights have been grounded and what you can do if you're affected, here:&nbspThousands of holidaymakers have had their flights cancelled and delayed&nbsp due to systems failuresWorrying figures out today suggest&nbspthat five million&nbsppension&nbspsavers could be susceptible to the common tactics used by scammers to steal retirement savings.&nbspPresented with six common scam scenarios, two-fifths of 45 to 65-year-olds said they would act in one or more ways which experts said could leave them exposed to fraud.&nbspThe data comes from a poll by the Financial Conduct Authority and the&nbspPensions Regulator.&nbspPeople should be wary of warning signs such as: pension&nbspcold calls, free&nbsppension&nbspreviews, claims of guaranteed high returns, exotic investments, time-limited offers, and promises of early access to cash.Back to potential food shortages after Brexit.&nbspWhat can consumers&nbspexpect? Unfortunately, even the food industry, which has tested a range of options to mitigate the effect of massive disruption at Dover, doesn't really know.&nbspFood and Drink Federation boss Tim Rycroft tells the BBC:&nbsp&nbspThere will be selective shortages and they will to some extent be random because it depends on which trucks get through and which don't. We think there will be some serious disruption and it will go on for weeks or months after our exit.The government is unlikely to grant the food industry's wish for&nbsprelaxed rules to alleviate food supply problems, says Mark Jones, partner at law firm Gordons. Big supermarkets&nbspprobably won't&nbspbe on board either.Jones says: “The ‘big four’ control almost 70 per cent&nbspof the market and if any of them have a supply chain advantage post-Brexit, it offers them an opportunity to gain market share, says Jones.&nbspI cannot see them wanting to help their competitors. They will want to help their own customers.&nbsp&nbsp“As to suppliers, if they can sell the stock they have, they will, and they may well be able to make a better profit if supply is tight. &nbspIf they cannot sell or use their raw materials, there is nothing stopping them picking up the phone to their competitors and selling raw materials now. &nbspRelaxing rules on anti-competitive behaviour is, in my view, unlikely to help shortages and I cannot see the Government going for it.”&nbspThe pound is a quarter of a per cent lower against the dollar so far today at $1.2137, not far off the 31-month low of $1.2080 it hit last week.&nbspAgainst the euro, sterling is down 0.1 of a cent, leaving it slightly above the 23-month low reached yesterday.&nbspWith little to look out for on the economic calendar, Connor Cambell, financial analyst at Spreadex, predicts markets will remain incredibly susceptible to the minutiae of the trade war and comments from Donald Trump.Twitter has revealed it may have used some people's personal data to target them with advertising without their permission because of issues within the platform's settings, the&nbspPress Association&nbspreports.The social media giant said it had recently discovered issues in its website where settings choices may not have worked as intended, resulting in some gathered data being used to personalise advertising.Twitter said it fixed the issues on 5 August.In a blog post discussing the problems, Twitter detailed how, in one case, data may have been shared with advertisers despite not receiving user permission to do so.Donald Trump's trade war with China has pushed oil prices to a new seven-month low as the outlook for the global economy looks increasingly bleak.&nbspBrent crude is down 0.6&nbspper cent to $58.31.&nbspThe US president attacked Beijing this week for allegedly manipulating its currency to make Chinese exports more competitive.&nbsp&nbspThe UK government is yet to respond to a request by the food industry to waive parts of competition law so that companies can cooperate after a no-deal&nbspBrexit&nbspto mitigate&nbspfood shortages.&nbspFull story from story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsNeither the Bixby&nbspsmart assistant nor virtual reality made an appearance at Samsung's latest tech showcaseClick to followThe Independent TechSamsung unveiled the world's most powerful smartphones in New York this week, in the form of the Galaxy Note 10 and the Note 10+, alongside its vision for the future of personal electronics.Company CEO DJ Koh&nbspstressed the value of 5G, augmented reality and even high-tech styluses in his presentation, summed up by the tagline: Experience Innovation. But there were two technologies that were notably absent from the Unpacked event.Neither Samsung's virtual assistant Bixby nor VR compatibility for the Note 10&nbspreceived a single mention during the nearly two-hour tech&nbspshowcase. Both have been heavily hyped in recent years, but their quiet omission&nbspsuggests they may no longer be central to Samsung's grander ambitions.Bixby has not been forgotten entirely, with both the Note 10 and Note 10+ supporting the virtual assistant. But Samsung's answer to Apple's Siri and Amazon's Alexa was not called upon or showed off during any of the product demos.At the same venue in 2018, Samsung unveiled the Bixby-supported Galaxy Home, which was designed to offer an alternative to other smart speakers like the Amazon Echo, Apple HomePod and Google Home. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.The ancient symbiosis of beasts roaming forested land is being reintroduced to our fields – albeit in modern ways that are more likely to involve chickens and raspberries&nbspthan wolves and alder, writes Emily ClarkClick to followThe IndependentIn a field somewhere in Wiltshire, there is an unassuming row of raspberry canes growing in a grassy, weed-tangled patch with a happy tale to tell. The summer before last, this plot would have been filled with the sound of 70 laying hens clucking as they roamed about, scratching at the weeds around the raspberries.As part of this hen-and-berry experiment, some canes had been fenced off. The chickens, like tiny bio-tractors, went about delivering nutrient-rich manure to the land around the other plants. The hens benefited from freedom and green space. And the raspberry canes they visited? They grew quicker and fruited earlier than the ones beyond the fence boundary. Even now, after nearly two years without chickens, they are still much better plants.Alas, this story doesn’t end quite so well for the hens. Their merry outdoor tramping proved too tempting for kites, buzzards and kestrels, and several were plucked right out of raspberry paradise and eaten up.Nevertheless, this experiment was worthwhile – it is an example of the mixed style of farming that could help our crops, farm animals and soils thrive.There is a word for this method and it’s buzzing across Britain’s fields: agroforestry. If you listen to The Archers, you’re probably thinking that you’ve heard about it on there. If you don’t, you’re probably thinking about how unbearable The Archers is.For the anti-Ambridge brigade, agroforestry is when farmers plant trees (or shrubs and bushes like raspberries) in their fields – and it can help solve many of the problems facing our farmers.Created with Sketch.Agroforestry at Eastbrook Farm Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Eastbrook Farm in Wiltshire has dozens of organic pigs. The farm is interested in moving them to rootle around under trees instead of fields, but they have to be among older, resilient trees whose roots are well established. The farm's Ben Raskin points to the pigs in Spanish and Portugese dehesa systems that are mixed in with cork and oak trees, feeding on the acorns. Cows enjoy the shade and shelter of trees – and munching on their leaves. The energy they save has been shown to increase the efficiency of dairy farming. The Soil Association says agroforestry increases milk production by 17 per cent, and reduces lamb mortality by 50 per cent. A neat row of almond trees at Eastbrook, in their fourth year of growth. As long as there is not a late frost, the blossom and nuts will do well. A climate-conscious diet may see Britons turn away from factory-farmed meat and towards plant protein – could homegrown almonds become a British staple? A moth sits on thistles that grow between the young trees. Agroforestry is great for wildlife – from the littlest critters to the birds and bees. Blackcurrants growing on the farm are used at the adjoining pub. Trees and shrubs can ersify farmers’ income streams. It may be more awkward to have to sell a variety of produce to different places, rather than only growing one crop for a supermarket, but if that one crop fails they could be more financially vulnerable. A ginkgo tree with a tag for monitoring and measuring growth and health. Gingkos have been found in fossils that are 270 million years old – meaning they evolved with the dinosaurs – and it is believed to be the oldest tree species. Gingko leaves and nuts are used herbal teas and medicines. It’s also interesting in that it has no tree species relatives. However, Ben says it isn’t particularly enjoying life on the farm… What looks like a jumble of weeds and grasses in fact tells a wonderful tale. These are young raspberry canes, which 70 chickens were allowed to peck around for several months. The birds tramped around on woodchip, stopping weeds germinating, and adding nutrients via manure. The canes developed noticeably more happily than the nearby ones that the chickens were penned off from – they grew quicker and fruited earlier than those without, and even now two years later are still the much better plants. However, some of the chickens were eaten by kites, buzzards and kestrels, so the system hasn’t quite proven itself just yet. A perry company is buying pears from Eastbrook. Apples and pear trees are trusted by farmers, whereas almonds and peaches are more exotic, with more unknowns. In a grassy 45-acre field, a large area has been fenced off. You can’t quite see the young willows that have been planted, for timber, but far in the distance, a few have excitedly shot up after a pile of woodchip was stored on them. Ben was not expecting this – but says the retained soil moisture and weedkilling properties must be responsible. Ben, who is encouraging farmers to branch out with their tree species, checks out the tag on a golden glow apricot tree. He says: “As a horticulturalist, I am of course excited to be pushing the boundaries a little and planting things like almonds and apricots in a location and system that probably hasn’t been tried before. However what really drives me is to explore the potential of the whole system. Will the timber trees do better with a coppiced alder next to them? Will our soil health improve? Can we demonstrate improved productivity of the whole farm as many agroforestry systems do?” Eastbrook Farm in Wiltshire has dozens of organic pigs. However what really drives me is to explore the potential of the whole system. Will the timber trees do better with a coppiced alder next to them? Will our soil health improve? Can we demonstrate improved productivity of the whole farm as many agroforestry systems do?” Soil erosion is one of the most concerning. This happens when soil is washed and blown away by rain and wind. Some 3 million tons of topsoil are lost in the UK each year, according to the Campaign to Protect Rural England. And British soils may have only 100 harvests left, warn scientists from the University of Sheffield.&nbspBut trees protect soil: their roots provide stabilising infrastructure, creating channels where water is held, while their bodies act&nbspas wind-blockers. These factors will come in even more useful with the increasingly violent floods and storms caused by climate change. In a few decades’ time, we may be relying on agroforestry techniques just to ensure we can still feed ourselves.&nbspThe roots of trees also dig deeper than crops, allowing them to bring up more nutrients&nbsp – mainly nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium – from below. The nutrients spread to the leaves, which then fall on the soil and feed crops, if they are being grown alongside. This is nature’s fertiliser and could help farmers cut their pesticide costs as well as revitalise tired, one-crop fields.&nbspEastbrook Farm in Wiltshire lets its organic pigs&nbsprootle around under trees instead of fields&nbsp(Emily Clark)Trees also provide habitats for wildlife down in the earth’s crust and above it – giving home to the birds, critters and insects that are in alarming decline in Britain, whose existence we depend upon for our ecosystem.And crucially, trees suck up carbon, which is why planting them is key to the government’s climate strategy. More and more, trees are hitting headlines as solutions to our climate crisis. The government advisers at the Committee on Climate Change say 30,000 hectares of woodland should be planted every year until 2050 to meet the UK’s goal of net zero carbon at that point. That’s 1.5 billion trees in total.Farmers have come to see trees as a problem rather than something of value. If you’ve got a big oak tree in the middle of your field, you don’t think, ‘It’s great to have a habitat for all the stuff around oak trees’, you think, ‘I’ve got to bloody drive round that in my plough’The committee, made up of science and business experts, adds that the 30,000 hectare figure may have to be revised up to 50,000 if other climate promises aren’t met.&nbspLast year, England was 7 million trees short of the target for just 5,000 hectares, so there will have to be huge changes to keep us on track – putting agroforestry in the spotlight. It’s likely that the benefits of tree planting will align with the environment-focused farming subsidies that replace the EU payments after Brexit.There are still more benefits from farm trees – animals allowed to graze among them are given shade and shelter. This means they need less feed to keep warm or cool, and gives them a wider diet. The fruit, nuts, fuel logs or timber from trees and bushes then create another income stream for farmers.&nbspWith all this, you would think farmers would be keen on agroforestry. But modern farming, which has crept up on us since the industrial revolution and inspired today’s chemical-soaked monocrops, has seen farmers become reluctant to keep hedges, bushes and trees.&nbspMany tore these wilder spaces up so they could profit from crops instead – every inch of field matters when margins are tight. In our mad farming subsidy matrix, which encourages farming with yield-boosting pesticides, who could blame them? (Tearing out long farm hedgerows did become illegal in 1997.)Our version of capitalism has also created incentive to farm lots of one thing – high street chains and supermarkets want to make life easy for themselves by having fewer suppliers who can deliver bulk orders. But eventually, the huge monocrop fields that are fuelled on chemicals will become infertile, and what then?The good news is that, if done carefully, planting trees can boost productivity by up to a third, according to the Soil Association (SA). It can be done in an environmentally sustainable way that also makes financial sense.When cows munch on tree leaves, their&nbspdiet is improved and tree growth is stimulated –&nbspmulberry leaves are high in protein and willow bark has painkilling properties. Or when chickens trample down the weeds around young trees, they are stifling the competition. As with the hens and raspberries, animal manure then fertilises the soil – helping trees or crops grow.&nbspFarmers were being paid to rip out hedges so that fields got bigger. As a result we’ve now got lots of really big fields, with nothing but one crop in it, which is actually quite a vulnerable, fragile position to be inBut before taking the risk of buying trees and rethinking their farm systems, farmers need sound advice to know what’s best for their animals or crops. There are a million agroforestry variations, and a million factors – soil type, tree species, choice of animal, grazing time, fencing, market demands, wind direction, labour costs, stubborn landowners… pass the paracetamol.&nbspThis is a long game, and the financial stakes are high – it can take 10 to 15 years to establish a raspberry cane, and growing oak for timber can take 100 years.But there is advice out there. Ben Raskin, head of horticulture at the SA, is in his third year of testing out more than 20 tree species at Eastbrook Farm in Wiltshire – belonging to SA chief executive Helen Browning. He oversaw the raspberry and chicken combination, just one example of his many devious schemes.&nbspHe’s particularly excited about growing almonds and apricots (now feasible thanks to global warming) in a location that hasn’t been tried before… in other words, California dreamin’. Raskin has now put together a handbook for farmers explaining how to move into agroforestry, produced by the SA and the Farm Woodland Forum.&nbspHe says at least one farmer a week comes over to ask about his agroforestry experiments – four came the week before I visited, with 1,000 acres between them, and officials from Defra were booked in the following week.&nbspRaskin&nbspis encouraging farmers to branch out with the tree species they&nbspchoose to plant&nbsp(Emily Clark)Before showing me his neat rows of young trees including peach, pear, cherry and damson, he explains why this type of farming is blossoming in Britain – after 150 years of decline.&nbsp“Long, long ago, farmers would have made quite a lot of use of trees, and hedgerows would have been quite productive,” he says. “They would have had fruit and nuts and they would have coppiced them for fuel.”As industrialisation took hold, and farmers began to specialise, the story changed. “We were getting bigger tractors and becoming more efficient at farming,” Raskin says, “so farmers were being paid to rip out hedges so that fields got bigger. As a result we’ve now got lots of really big fields, with nothing but one crop in it, which is actually quite a vulnerable, fragile position to be in.How small farms are leading the way towards sustainable agricultureFarming chief calls for ‘net zero’ agriculture emissions in UK by 2040‘Super crops’ could revolutionise agriculture in Africa, expert claims“Farmers have come to see trees as a problem rather than something of value, something that’s worth spending time on. If you’ve got a big oak tree in the middle of your field, you don’t think, ‘It’s great to have a habitat for all the stuff around oak trees’, you think, ‘I’ve got to bloody drive round that in my plough’. However, trees do bring a whole massive range of benefits to a farm.”&nbspA lot of countries are way ahead of us on this, he says, including France, China, America&nbspand tropical countries that never lost the art. In Spain and Portugal’s dehesa systems, pigs are mixed in with cork and oak trees, feeding on the acorns.&nbspRaskin points to a few agroforestry operations in the UK – the Pontbren lamb project in Wales involving 10 farmers is one that has been a particular success. They realised during the Nineties that they were spending too much on feed and housing costs for their lambs. To keep the lambs outside for longer, they knew the animals would need more shelter – so they began planting thousands of trees.&nbspTheir plans worked. But the farmers also realised that the woodland absorbed 60 times more water than pasture fields just 10 metres away. The trees they had planted in the wettest parts of Wales were a brilliant defence against flooding in other parts of the country.&nbspThere were also fewer chemicals running into waterways from compacted soils on intensive farms. And better shelter is&nbspknown to&nbspreduce flock health issues, such as lameness or even death of the youngest lambs.But Raskin says there are still very few examples of agroforestry in the UK – and we’ve got to up our game.&nbspWith the barrage of difficulties faced by our farmers, especially as Brexit uproots the subsidy system, they’re going to need all the help they can get. title: pound live dollar euro exchange rate brexit no deal gbp usd
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsFollow the latest business updatesClick to followThe IndependentThe pound is set to fall even further as the likelihood increases of a no-deal Brexit that will be disastrous for the UK economy, according to a poll.Sterling has already suffered a rout since Boris Johnson became prime minister on 24 July, falling to a two-and-a-half year low against the dollar of $1.2080 last week.Analysts polled by Reuters predicted further declines to between $1.17 and $1.20 as the 31 October deadline day approaches.Please allow a moment for the live blog to loadPound to be worth less than dollar for first time ever after no-deal Brexit, analyst forecastsUK-based pilots working for Ryanair and belonging to the British Airline Pilots Association (Balpa) are going on strike.&nbspHere is everything you need to know from our senior travel editor Simon Calder.&nbsp&nbspNationwide is returning £6m to more than&nbsp320,000 of its customers after the Competition and Markets Authority found that the bank had failed to alert the customers before charging them for unarranged overdrafts.&nbspThe CMA introduced an order in February last year stating that bank customers with personal current accounts must receive a text alert before the charges can be levied. The order was aimed at giving customers the opportunity to avoid unexpected fees.&nbspMore bad Brexit news for homeowners?The&nbspUK housing market&nbspis stuck in a holding pattern as buyers wait for more clarity on&nbspBrexit&nbspbefore committing to a purchase that could prove unwise if Britain crashes out of the EU in October, reports Olesya Dmitracova.Political and economic uncertainty has driven UK residential transactions at Savills to their lowest level since the financial crisis, the estate agency, one of the nation’s largest, said in its half-year earnings report on Thursday.&nbspA fall in home sales was also revealed in the July survey by the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors, and earlier this week Halifax said sales had dropped during the early months of the summer.Full report here:Housing market loses momentum as UK inches closer to no-deal BrexitLiz Truss, the UK’s international trade secretary, is speaking to the right-wing US think tank the Heritage Foundation today about a trade deal with the US.The ultra-free-market organisation is committed to cutting environmental regulations and other protections.Ms Truss met privately with the group last year, documents obtained by Greenpeace’s investigative unit Unearthed&nbsprevealed this week.Among the topics discussed were “what we can learn from ‘Reaganomics’ on things like regulation and red tape”.The FTSE-100 index is up 19.42 at 7218.12.&nbspThe pound is broadly flat so far today against both the euro and dollar.Troubling reading in the UN's climate change report released today which says that humans need to urgently change their diets to avoid catastrophic levels of global warming.&nbspThat will mean huge changes for the agriculture&nbspand food&nbspindustries.&nbspVicki Hird from Sustain, a British charity which advocates better food and farming, says: “The IPCC report proposes adopting farming practices that work with nature rather than forcing production with overuse of artificial fertilisers. &nbspA key step would be to end harmful subsidies of big single crops (such as corn, sugar cane, soy) and fossil fuels.”&nbspFull report here from science correspondent Phoebe Weston:&nbsp'A perfect storm': People must change diet and stop destroying land before it is too late, says major climate change report&nbspHargreaves Lansdown doesn't seem to have been hurt too badly by its involvement in the Neil Woodford fund scandal that has seen hundreds of thousands of customers unable to access their money.&nbspThe fund supermarket recommended Woodford's now-suspended fund through its best buy lists.&nbspIt says today that inflows of client funds have held up well since Woodford froze clients' cash in early June.A plummeting pound of course means reduced spending power&nbspfor British holidaymakers heading away this month.&nbspAs always, even the best rates for consumers are some way below the market rate.&nbsp&nbspAt the best of the large foreign exchange providers, £750 will now buy you:&nbspeuros:&nbspDebenhams - €801.75M&ampS Bank - €801Post Office - €800.25&nbspor, for dollars:&nbspDebenhams - $898.50Post Office - $897Sainsbury’s Bank - $897Figures courtesy of MoneyBrexit has put some people off buying or selling a home, says upmarket estate agent Savills, which reported results today.&nbspSales of UK property are at the lowest level since the financial crisis while protests in Hong Kong also dented the market there, Savills says.&nbspChief executive&nbspMark Ridley: “In many markets, particularly the UK and Hong Kong, political and economic uncertainty has considerably reduced the volume of real estate trading activity in recent months, although occupier demand remains robust.&nbspHalf-year pre-tax profits fell 12 per cent to £38.4m in the six months to 30 June.&nbspWhile interest rates and economic data would normally drive the value of the pound, right now the primary factor by a long distance is the perceived probability that the UK will leave the EU with no deal on 31 October.&nbspThe more likely it appears to be, the lower the pound goes.&nbspThis morning brings news of another plan MPs have hatched to prevent that outcome, which a majority of them - and the public - want to avoid.&nbspMPs are considering a bid to cancel the annual autumn recess set aside for party conferences in a fresh attempt to prevent Boris Johnson ploughing ahead with a no-deal Brexit, our political correspondent Ashley Cowburn reports.&nbspBrexit: MPs considering bid to ‘cancel autumn recess’ to stop Halloween no-dealSome better news today in stock markets that have suffered recently from fears surrounding an escalating trade war between the US&nbspand China.&nbspThe major indices edged up on the back of&nbspsurprise news that Chinese exports rose 3.3 per cent in July, despite rising tariffs imposed by Donald Trump's administration.&nbspImports were also up suggesting China is showing signs of resilience.&nbsp&nbsp- Japan's Nikkei 225 up 0.37 per cent to 20,593.35.&nbsp- Hong Kong's Hang Seng up 0.5 per cent to 26,120.77&nbsp- Germany's Dax up 0.5 per cent to 11,712.12&nbsp- France's CAC 40 up 1 per cent to 5,317.74&nbsp- FTSE 100 up 0.14 per cent to 7,208.62What would the economy look like after a no-deal Brexit with&nbspone&nbsppound worth less than one dollar?&nbspPretty dreadul, according to Silvia Dall’Angelo, Senior Economist at Hermes Investment Management:&nbspA sharp currency depreciation would act as a supply-side shock, driving a spike in inflation, a squeeze on income and a drag on consumption. Savings would fail to provide an ample buffer as consumers have already dissaved significantly since the EU referendum. In fact, the saving rate is running close to its record low levels.&nbsp&nbspBusiness investment may also slow further as a falling pound with potential for further depreciation could spook investors. Furthermore, the benefit of rising exports usually associated with a weaker currency has not yet been felt by UK businesses, which suggests we may see little boost to exports from a weak pound.&nbspLooking beyond pound v dollar, things are even worse for the pound.&nbspAgainst a trade-weighted basket of major currencies, sterling hit a 33-month low on 30 July&nbspSterling’s recent tumble suggests that a no-deal Brexit could take the pound into uncharted territory, says&nbspSilvia Dall’Angelo, Senior Economist at Hermes Investment Management.&nbspAgainst the dollar, that could mean $1.05 to $1.10 but, Given the tendency for financial markets to overshoot, no-deal Brexit could easily push the pound to parity with the dollar which has never happened before.&nbspShe adds:&nbspGoing forward, there is scope for wider ranges of value for the pound, including the possibility of an increase if MPs are able to successfully block a no-deal Brexit in Parliament, but realistically, the next few months don’t hold much promise for the currency. &nbspSeptember and October could be wildly volatile months for sterling.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. It’s a human being. You’re sending mass amounts of messaging to this person to either shut up, disappear, or it could also be perceived as, Kill yourself. I realised I needed to restructure my life because it felt completely out of control. I knew immediately I needed to make music about it because I knew it was the only way I could survive it. It was the only way I could preserve my mental health and also tell the story of what it’s like to go through something so humiliating.”Created with Sketch.From beef to BFFs to beef again: Kanye West and Taylor Swift Show all 6Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.NEW YORK - SEPTEMBER 13:   Kanye West (L) jumps onstage after Taylor Swift (C) won the Best Female Video award during the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards at Radio City Music Hall on September 13, 2009 in New York City. Morgan hit 17 sixes and set a new record in one-day international cricket, which saw his side win by 150 runsBut why is&nbspScottish independence in the headlines again?The short answer is because of Boris Johnson’s arrival in Downing Street, shifting the government’s Brexit stance towards a no-deal departure.Mr Johnson has tried to put the preservation of&nbspthe UK at the heart of his premiership, by visiting the devolved governments early and by describing himself as “minister for the union”.However, his visit to Edinburgh, where he was booed and jeered by protesters, seems to have done more harm than good.A shock&nbsppoll, conducted in the wake of his trip, put backing for&nbspScottish independence&nbspat 46 per cent, with 43 per cent of voters against.Support for independence rose to 52 per cent, with 48 per cent against, when those who said they did not know how they would vote or said they would not vote were removed.The poll by Lord Ashcroft –&nbspthe first to show a lead for Scottish independence since 2017 – had a major impact.Nicola Sturgeon, the Scottish first minister, said it delivered a “phenomenal” boost for the independence movement, as Scotland was “dragged towards a no-deal Brexit”.While it is only one poll, the Ashcroft findings illustrate the growing threat to the union from a no-deal Brexit.By law, Scotland must seek the UK government’s approval to hold another referendum, as matters relating to the union of the United Kingdom are referred to Westminster.Majority of Scots back independence in shock poll after Johnson visitAfter the 2014 vote, Sturgeon&nbspkept her troops at the top of the hill for some time.She eventually requested consent from Theresa May in March 2017, the day before the then-prime minister fired the starting gun on the Brexit process.May blocked the move, saying it was “not the time” for more constitutional upheaval. Sturgeon tried again in April 2019 but the request was again denied.In May, the Scottish government published a bill laying out the framework for a second independence referendum once it has been granted powers by Westminster.Using a similar framework to previous referendums, the bill would allow a new vote quickly as Holyrood would not need to pass another law. The question and the date would need parliamentary approval under the plan.If the referendum question were the same as in the 2014 poll,&nbspthere would be no need for further testing by the Electoral Commission.There is a small majority for independence in the Scottish parliament, as the&nbspScottish Greens would join the SNP to form a 68-strong bloc in the 129-seat parliament.All of the remaining Holyrood&nbspparties are opposed to Scotland leaving the UK.The problem for Sturgeon is all her preparations hinge on getting the nod from Westminster – and that remains an unlikely prospect.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Morgan hit 17 sixes and set a new record in one-day international cricket, which saw his side win by 150 runsEconomists agree that the housing market will suffer if Britain leaves the EU without a deal.&nbspThe government’s spending watchdog, the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), forecast last month that house prices would tumble by almost 6 per cent in 2020 and another 3 per cent in 2021. The slide could be even steeper as the OBR’s prediction was based on the assumption of a particular type of no-deal Brexit – the less disruptive of the two laid out by the IMF earlier this year.Howard Archer, economic adviser to the EY Item&nbspClub, forecasts a similar decline, saying house prices would quickly fall by about 5 per cent as the economy weakened and the market was mired in acute uncertainty over Britain’s future trading relationship with the EU.For now, house prices look on track for hardly any growth over this year.&nbspAccording to RICS, a net balance of 9 per cent of respondents reported a fall in average prices over the past three months in England and Wales. Samuel Tombs, economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said the result is consistent with the official measure of prices showing a rise of only 0.5 per cent in 2019.&nbspHalifax data also showed that UK house prices dropped slightly in July for the second consecutive month and now stand at £236,120 on average.“The market continues to tread water,” said Russell Galley, managing director at Halifax.&nbsp“In the longer term, we believe there is unlikely to be a step change in market activity until buyers and sellers see some form of resolution to the current economic uncertainty.”RICS echoed this prediction, noting that its survey now points to zero growth in sales – as well as a steeper fall in prices – in the next three months.On Thursday Boris Johnson reiterated his trademark message that Britain will leave the EU on 31 October, even though no progress has been made on securing a withdrawal agreement acceptable to both sides.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. I was being polite.The moment Samantha shared anything on Facebook, Deal would like or comment on it.Then last September, the rapper tried to gatecrash a VIP tent Samantha was in at the Bournemouth Air Festival - and posted a live blog on Facebook claiming he was in love with her.The same month, he turned up at the Miss England finals at Nottinghams prestigious Kelham Hall, where Samantha made the top  and was crowned Miss South Coast Charity Queen after attending more than  charity events in  months.It was here he disturbingly told people he was her boyfriend, before lunging in to kiss her backstage.I felt like a real-le princess that night, says Samantha, now a teaching assistant.I had a real diamond tiara on my head, worth £,, and I had a dress on that was stunning.She adds: Out the back, theres a little arch we walk through - Deal literally grabbed me and went to hug me and kiss my lips. I felt physically sick - his breath near mine made me shiver.It was a huge moment and he ruined it.Samantha managed to push her stalker off before fleeing to find her parents.But when she told them what had just happened, she was sickened to discover that Deal had been wandering around looking for her and had even tried to sit at her familys table to get close to her.They hadnt seen him [lunge at me] but I said, hes just tried to kiss me, she says.They said, the moment its finished, were leaving. I called them twice a day sometimes, panicking.She was relieved when, in February, Deal was finally caged for  weeks and handed an indefinite restraining order banning him from any form of contact with her, after he admitted harassment.But Samanthas stress ed only three months later when she discovered the con had been freed early, on May .Id felt so good knowing he was behind bars - there was no way he could stalk me or anyone near me - [but] after he was released I struggled, she says.I had a special doorbell fitted in my familys house. The doorbell rings and we can see whos at the door - andsomeone walks past the door we can see them.She adds: I was going round the house locking all the doors.Incredibly, on May , just four days after his release, Deal broke the terms of his restraining order by re-posting messages on Facebook relating to the Miss Dorset and Miss England contests Samantha had participated in.The rapper was hauled before Poole Magistrates Court last month, where he was convicted of two counts of breaching the order and sent back to prison for  weeks.But Samantha fears his short sentence means he could soon terrorise someone  - and has backed calls for a national stalking register to protect women from predators like Deal.The moment you come across Jonathan Deal, block him, she warns.Dont give him the time of day or a chance. I should have blocked him a lot earlier.She adds: If there was a register, Deal would have been known and dealt with a lot quicker.Later this year, Stalking Protection Orders- backed by The Sun - will come into effect to help protect victims.More than one in five women and almost one in  men aged  to  have been victims of stalking since the age of , according to the Crime Survey for England and Wales.SPOs will prevent stalkers from contacting victims or approaching them through those around them - and will force them to register their name, address and any aliases they use.Offenders may also be banned from ­loitering near victims’ homes.A breach of the order will be punishable by up to five years behind bars.Today, while Deal languishes in jail, Samantha is looking ahead to the Miss Sovereign GB pageant - a contest that aims to empower girls and women while raising funds for charity.She decided to enter the pageant to help others and raise awareness of stalking - but is understandably taking a very dferent approach towards social media and her fans.I havent added anyone that I dont know recently and that is big for me, Samantha says. the States for mysterious government facilities linked with UFOs.Nick Pope ran the Ministry of Defences UFO project in the s, looking into reports of flying saucers, crop circles, and even abductions. Here he reveals the secret spots that might be Britains Area . RAF Rudloe Manor, WiltshireTheory: Alien technology being kept in secret underground labFor years, conspiracy theorists alone.Within moments, military police turned up and halted filming, further fuelling the conspiracy theories.Ministry of Defence Main Building, LondonTheory: UFO investigations team officially shutdown but still running in secretInside Room  in the MoD Main Building in Whitehall, the governments main UFO project looked into the strange reports of flying saucers around the UK.In the  years the project ran until , around , cases were looked into by the team.Although most were debunked, around five per cent of the cases couldnt be explained.And although the project was officially closed down a decade ago, Nick believes it still operating but now in secret.He claims a source in the MoD told him Americans were now running the project.And another told him investigations have just moved primary location where alien tech would be keptThe Royal Aerospace Establishment at Farnborough, Hampshire has previously been called Britain’s Area .RAE Farnborough was originally set up as an aircraft and weapons research facility at the turn of the twentieth century and closed in the late s.In , a y report by conspiracy theorists claimed the site was well-connected to UFO sightings — and even alien abductions.Rumours persist, and Farnborough is currently home to QinetiQ, a defence technology company that researches and develops cutting-edge equipment including weapons, robotics and space-related tech.And Nick saysthe UK ever did get hold of extraterrestrial tech, it probably wouldve been sent to Farnborough for study.But he also wants to pour cold water on the claims that the title: avoid publicity paul hollywood ask oscar winning judi dench
story: All the drama in his le — the latest being dumped by girlfriend Summer Monteys-Fullam after asking her to sign a laughably self-important “gagging order” — is entirely of his own making.Yet, in an Instagram post richer than triple chocolate mousse, he seemingly blames her for the media attention they attract. He also adds that: “I prefer a quiet le away from the day job.” And the band played Believe It If You Like.To recap: Paul is a master baker who caught a lucky break after being booked to appear on what became TV juggernaut The Great British Bake Off.Back then he was happily married to we Alex and, outside of an occasional media interview to plug the show, his home le never made the headlines.A bit of work and no play made Paul a dull boy when it came to clickbait. Then he had a fling with fellow TV chef Marcela Valladolid and all hell broke loose.Sex sells. It always has. So does scandal, and cheating on your we with a younger woman fits firmly into both categories.When the fling ended, the admirably forgiving Alex took Paul back, but the marriage faltered again and he took up with a -year-old barmaid with a fondness for miniskirts and crop tops.What’s not to love for the hundreds of “paparazzo”who make a living from how many times their photo gets viewed online It’s not rocket science, is it  Earlier this year I spotted Judi Dench out supermarket shopping.Yes, that Judi Dench. Dame of the British Empire. Oscar winner. Recipient of more awards than Mr Hollywood’s had hot buns.And favoured guest of chatshow host Graham Norton. Time will tell.But suffice to say, he’s already shaping up to be the UK’s cheerleader – a feat the more reserved and aloof Theresa May never quite managed.WHEN asked about children, Prince Harry replied that he and we Meghan might have “two, maximum”.Fair enough, I thought. After all, she’s  now and,she’s lucky, Mother Nature might let her conceive one more before her womb shuts shop.But no, it seems the royal couple’s decision is to do with population growth, despite experts saying that, globally, the birthrate is shrinking and the real issue is how long we’re all living.So unless he’s planning to pack Granny off to Dignitas, there’s not much he can do about it. But I digress.Regarding royal babies and, in particular, Harry and Meghan’s sensitivity around their firstborn’s privacy, perhaps they should copy his cousin Zara.She and husband Mike Tindall have two daughters, Mia, five, and Lena, one. There’s no showboating or churlishness, they just give their daughters as normal a le as possible via picnics, getting muddy, painting faces and rough and tumble – as seen in thisdelightful photo of mischievous Mia hitching a ride on Dad’s back.They occasionally get photographed, but clearly accept that it’s just one of those things and don’t let it bother them. A parenting template to be admired, whoever you are.THE author Alex Elle once said: “I am very cautious of people whose actions don’t match their words.”In which case, let’s hope she wasn’t invited to the recent Google Camp party in Sicily which,you’re one of the self-regarding A-listers in attendance, was a high-minded gathering to discuss the issue of climate change.Or to the rest of us – a boondoggle for entitled fools. How  to describe an event attended by  of some of the world’s richest people who arrived on eco-unfriendly private jets and luxury yachts Oh, the unacknowledged irony. Meanwhile, Leona Lewis and ious other celebrities, who advocate gun control, happily took a shilling or three to attend the Austria-based party of Gaston Glock – one of the world’s most famous gun makers.But back to Google Camp where – and I can’t quite believe I’m writing this – residents and hotel guests near the archaeological site of Selinunte were told by police to avoid looking out of their windows to protect the privacy of the invited A-listers dining al fresco.The same slebs, one assumes, who regularly virtue signal their moral credentials by advocating a world without borders, where everyone should be treated the same . . . yada yada. If hypocrisy was a movie, they’d all be winning Oscars.SCHOOLBOY Jay Hughes, , was talking to a friend outside a chicken shop in South London when a van pulled up and three men armed with machetes jumped out.His friend ran off and escaped but Jay stood in the shop doorway, where -year-old Nyron Jean-Baptiste stabbed him before boasting, “I got one”, and leaving the scene.Jean-Baptiste has now been jailed for “le” – whatever that means these days – while poor Jay’s distraught mother Cindy has been condemned to a letime of painful loss.Another devastated mother, Linda Burke-Monerville, spoke last month about sending her remaining children back to Nigeria for safety after losing three of her sons to violent crime in the UK.What on earth is happening to this country  Entire communities feel they have been abandoned by the police while criminal gangs rule by fear – and no one in power seems to know what to do about it.New Home Secretary Priti Patel said this week that she is resolutely focused on restoring law and order to our streets via extra police officers with greater powers.Talk is cheap – particularly when uttered by the majority of politicians. story: Little Lilly Worsfold, , was engulfed in a toxic cloud after the p adhesive made contact with the cotton-and-Lycra garment.Primark has launched an urgent investigation into the product after Lilly’s mum Louise posted a shocking video of the dramatic chemical reaction.Nursery manager Louise, , said: “I allowed Lilly to buy some pink plastic nails and a bottle of nail glue from Primark as a summer holiday treat.“She’s used them before - usually she sticks them on and they fall off a few days later.“But on this occasion she spilt a tiny amount of the glue on her leggings and they suddenly started smoking. Lilly can’t go swimming or to the beach and has to keep her legs elevated as much as possible. She’s also facing the prospect of surgery.“On top of that, she’s terried of starting a new secondary school in September with horrible scars all over her legs.”Lilly spent £ of her pocket money on a set of pink plastic nails and p on a bottle of brush-on nail glue from Primark on Saturday.Both bore the chain’s “P.S.” beauty brand marketed at girls and young women.Lilly started applying the nails in the back of the car on the way home. title: no need to ditch traditional puds
story: More than a third of young diners have never eaten a spotted dick and a quarter have never had a slice of flan, according to a study.What’s more, a fth of Brits aged  to  have never tried Eton mess, banoffee pie or rhubarb crumble — and one in six last ate jelly and ice cream TEN years ago.Traditional puds celebrate seasonal ingredients and are a pleasure to make. In winter there is nothing quite as satisfying as a steaming jam roly-poly with custard.Trle, my favourite, dates back  years. The word originally meant a light dessert, literally “a nothing”.But many desserts are disappearing from our menus.It’s not just the unfortunate overtones of roly–poly and spotted dick that are putting people off.Today, sugar, eggs, dairy and bread are out of fashion. People are opting for healthier desserts. Trendy cafes serve raw, dairy-free cakes.But I have to say “healthy dessert” is possibly the most disappointing combination of two words in the entire English language.Perhaps millennials are scared about the calories from eating out because of the growing pressure to look good on social media. If that’s the case, it’s very sad. Everything in moderation is fine.Processed food with lots of mysterious ingredients and high levels of salt and sugar is a very recent contrivance.Our grandparents ate ­simple, home-cooked meals made from fresh ingredients, and food was comparatively expensive, so people tended to eat smaller portions.Eat sensibly. You can enjoy sugar just as you might enjoy the occasional glass of wine.My kids love baking and making cakes is a great way to introduce them to cooking.Millennials are eating more fresh fruit, which is good. But food isn’t medicine. It should be something we look forward to and enjoy.Something that, eaten in moderation, will leave us feeling fully satisfied. And there are not many things that can do that for under a fiver.Here, I celebrate my favourite traditional puddings . . . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk holds the best cards brexit
story: We were warned about this before the referendum and have been told almost continuously for the past three years a British recession is just around the corner. But things aren’t quite working out that way.While the UK economy is far from booming, it is holding up much better than those in the Eurozone. Figures released yesterday show Germany’s manufacturing sector contracted by . per cent in July and is now a shocking . per cent smaller than it was a year ago.Given the importance of manufacturing to the German economy, it is likely the whole economy is now heading for recession — a fate the country only narrowly avoided at the end of last year.In Italy, too, economic growth has ground to a halt again — after the country only just hauled itself out of last year’s recession. In France, growth in the past three months fell to . per cent.By contrast, our economy looks relatively perky, with growth of . per cent in the three months to May. Figures released on Monday showed a rebound in confidence in the dominant services sector.Of the large Eurozone countries, only Spain is currently outgrowing us — but Spain is still recovering after a very deep recession from which it emerged in . In common with Italy, the Spanish economy is still smaller than it was before the - banking crisis.Not that you will hear any of this from Remainers. Every time a car factory is earmarked for closure or a steelworks runs into problems, we hear no end of people saying, “We told you so”.All bad news in the UK economy is automatically attributed to Brexit — on the BBC, especially. What we don’t hear is that manufacturing industries, especially cars and steel, are suffering the same problems across Europe.Germany’s car industry is still reeling from the scandal of Volkswagen cheating in emissions tests by installing software to detect when a car was in test mode.On top of that comes the proposed switch from petrol and diesel to electric cars. Many motorists — myself included — have put off buying new vehicles because we don’t know what to get.We have been told new petrol and diesel cars will be banned from  and worry they might be taxed out of existence well before then. Yet electric cars are still prohibitively expensive and can’t travel nearly far enough between charges.As for the steel industry, all across Europe it is struggling to compete with cheap competition from China — especially since the trade war with the US forced Chinese exporters to search for new markets away from America.Of course,we end up with a No-Deal Brexit and tarfs are imposed on imports and exports between Britain and the EU, it will cause some disruption to trade. But it is wrong to assume Britain will come off worse. In truth, EU exporters have more to lose. Britain runs a huge trade deficit with the EU.In  we exported £billion worth of goods and services to other EU countries and imported £billion from them — a trade gap of £billion. Moreover, EU exports to Britain are concentrated in products that attract relatively high tarfs.Cars, for example, attract an EU import tarf of ten per cent. If Britain chooses to impose that levy in reverse after Brexit, it will cause further mayhem in the German car industry.We also have a high deficit in food — which under EU rules attracts average tarfs of  per cent. For dairy products, the average EU import tarf is  per cent. If our Government decides to impose this on imports from the EU, it will mean the end of quite a few French cheese producers.Of course, the EU can avoid damaging these export industries by agreeing to a trade deal with the UK — one that doesn’t include the hated Irish backstop.Nearly half of Irish food exports go to the UK. Irish exports to other EU countries would be deeply affected as so many rely on UK roads. If there are delays at ports, traffic between Ireland and the Continent will suffer twice over — once crossing the Irish Sea then crossing the English Channel.EU leaders want to punish Britain for voting to leave their sacred project. They fear thatBritain is seen to do well, other countries will want to leave. But playing hardball with Britain will do deep harm to their own export industries.Does German chancellor Angela Merkel want to suffer the wrath of her country’s car makers  Does French president Emmanuel Macron wish to anger winemakers already struggling with an economic downturn at home A hard Brexit could cost Denmark as much as one per cent in lost gross domestic product. Their former economy minister Simon Emil Ammitzboll calls Brexit “the most visible threat to the Danish economy”.Holland and Belgium calculate similar falls will hit their economies, with the Dutch losing ten billion euros by . In Spain, wages for unskilled youths are lower than they were in the late s. Youth unemployment is a huge problem. Even qualied youths face a lower annual salary than their counterparts a decade ago.The alternative to all this is for the EU to swallow a bit of pride and agree to keep free trade flowing, perhaps via a temporary deal while long-term arrangements are negotiated.It won’t take much. Just remove the backstop — really just an underhand way of trying to keep Britain in the straitjacket of EU regulations and trade barriers — and some kind of withdrawal agreement would almost certainly make it through the Commons.If not, then yes, British industry will suffer in some ways from No Deal. But the Eurozone economies already lagging behind will take the bigger hit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris playing hardball eu from outset
story: First, he’s making the threat of No Deal serious. With Theresa May, it never was. Brussels knew she didn’t even want to leave, never mind with No Deal.Not any more. Second, he’s shaking up the civil service a bit.  It was civil servants who did most of the negotiating — and they are all wildly pro Remain.But with Boris’s adviser Dominic Cummings wielding the stick they might just be a little more amenable than before.Third — he’s realised that the bloody Northern Ireland backstop was never anywhere near so serious an impediment as the Remainersclaimed.And fourth, and maybe most importantly, he’s leading the country with a sense of optimism and chutzpah.Of course it’s Boris, so he may well do something totally bonkers and wreck the process. But so far he’s got everything right.He hasn’t got long to sort out a deal, the days are counting down. But my guess is that he WILL get one.The EU likes to talk a hard game but it usually budges in the end. It is desperate to avoid No Deal.Andit doesn’t budge — fine. A bumpy road for a few weeks and we’ll be OK, better off than ever. And free. The big threat to Brexit is not the EU — it’s our Parliament, once again.The Labour Party has ditched all semblance of principle and is now for a second referendum.Worse, Boris has a majority of only one. That’s not his fault — blame Theresa May for calling an election two years ago.It looks to me thatMagic Grandpa Jeremy Corbyn calls a vote of no confidence, he will probably win.Labour is already cosying up to the Scottish Nationalists and saying they wouldn’t mind a second referendum on independence.There is now nothing Labour wouldn’t do to gain power. Destroy the union and scupper Brexit — Magic Grandpa doesn’t care.Butthis whole thing ends with Labour des- troying Brexit, the party will never be trusted again.Oh sure, it will still get the votes from the metropolitan, middle-class lefties. But its working-class base will desert it, for good.So the message for Magic Grandpa is very clear. Win your vote of confidence, lose your voters. He’s not the brightest of men, but I do hope he grasps this.And Boris  Keep straight ahead. Play as hardball as possible with Brussels, knowing they want a deal. Strike as many deals with the likes of the USA and Canada as possible.And remind Brussels thatwe walk away without a deal, they don’t get a single penny from us. That should help to concentrate their minds for a while.This has been revealed in a new report by researchers with too much time on their hands. What these men want, I think, is the best of both worlds.I used to have a girlfriend who spent all day long sitting on the roof of the shed. Then she’d dart out into the road after a thrush. She was great.Had a little bell around her neck. And did her business in a small tray by the back door.A WOMAN in East London said nasty things to someone taking part in a gay Pride march. She was wearing a niqab, so the lefties didn’t get too cross.Still, it is at last beginning to dawn on the woke liberals that the more fervently Muslim a person may be, the less likely it is that he or she will take kindly to people who have a knack for interior design and enjoy watching Mamma Mia!.This has put them in a bit of a quandary. Much as have those largely Muslim protests outside schools in the Midlands which insist on teaching kids how wonderful gay relationships might be.The same sort of quandary that affects feminists, who are not entirely convinced that a ft chap with a todger and a beard who wishes to be called “Loretta” in the name of gender freedom actually is a woman.This is the thing with identity politics, protected characteristics and so on. Tug gently on one of its threads and the whole thing begins to unravel like a pink mohair jumper knitted by an imbecile. HERE’S some consol­ation for you cricket fans, in despair at our Ashes defeat. Steve Smith, the man who did most of the damage, is at least HALF English.He’s got an English mum and has dual nationality.He used to play cricket for a team in Sevenoaks, in Kent.So what we should do is ide his run total down the middle – we get half, the Aussies get half. That means we won the first Test. Fair dinkum Sometimes I think that one day I’ll be the only person left in the country paying tax.And I’ll get rung up by the Inland Revenue. “Sorry, Liddle, we need to fire off a few missiles to scare the Iranians. We’ll take it out of your next payment.”Thing is,people aren’t paying tax, or aren’t married to someone paying tax, should they have the vote THE way to pose for your Instagram shots this summer is to stand with your elbows in the air.Here is someone doing exactly that.And so everywhere you go this August, you will find young women doing a passable imitation of a cormorant.Those scented pine-tree things could obscure your view of oncoming traffic, apparently.Have to say, I wouldn’t mindthey were banned altogether. Especially that really sickly one that’s supposed to smell of coconut.Here’s a tip, mini-cab drivers. If you want your car to smell nice for passengers, maybe take a shower once in a while HANGING an air freshener from your car rear-view mirror could land you a fine.APPARENTLY,you stare hard at a seagull in a menacing fashion it will be too scared to nick your packet of chips.This is the new advice from the experts. I’ve known it all along. Stare hard at the bird asit’s just spilt your pint, or tried to chat up your girlfriend.And also add in a bit of abuse and threats for good measure. “You f***ing want some, you yellow-beaked t***er “I’ll cut you open like a tin of peaches, Sunshine.” Always works, until the Old Bill turn up. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn labour unfit government
story: But Labour are still lumbered with their dismal, discredited chief.Even as Jeremy Corbyn sinks deeper in the mire of unpopularity, his party makes no real attempt to dump him.Instead of taking action, Corbyn’s detractors just carp and criticise from the sidelines.Last week’s poor result in the Brecon and Radnorshire by-election, where the Labour candidate gained just five per cent of the vote, led to a new wave of condemnation.Former Northern Ireland Secretary Lord Hain said that Labours performance at Brecon had been truly dreadful, yet our current leadership carries on regardless towards disaster.Even more savage was another former Cabinet Minister Alan Johnson, one of the most respected Labour moderates, who said that practically anyone would be better in the job.Jeremy Corbyn is not just pious and sanctimonious, he’s useless at leading, which is why he has people around him to do his shoelaces and pull his strings, claimed Johnson.MORE IN COMMENT"
